page.title: 04ECOLOGY OF RIPPINGALE AREA
page.content: This is the edge of{fenland}through which small watercourses flow and are pumped to sea.Land is mainly arable, growing corn,sugarbeet,oilseed rape, potatoes and onions.There are few footpaths,some hedges of oak,ash and willow and small copses providing an abundance of fungi.The roadside edges have various grasses and common wild flowers.Birdlife consists of common species including barn owl,pheasant, partridge and winter migrants with occasional sparrowhawks and magpies. Animal life includes rats,fieldmice, shrews,stoats,foxes,rabbits,hares and, occasionally,grey squirrels and weasels.Common butterflies,bees,wasps and ladybirds are also present.A few plastic sacks litter fields and verges.Due to public opinion,stubble burning has been limited but chemical crop spraying still causes concern.
